reviews.review_text: A sequel to Steinbeck’s beloved Cannery Row this novel reprises a favored haunt of the author—with many of its old-friends denizens. Familiar landmarks also appear in post-war, tattered glory: the Palace Flophouse, Lee Chong’s Grocery store (under new management), the Bear Flag “establishment” and Doc’s messy but beloved Western Biological Laboratory.  Despite hard times and some painful memories the residents welcome Doc’s return home but gradually realize that something is wrong with their genial friend.  Things begin to pop at the arrival of peppy but down-at-heels Suzy; the sheriff sizes her up right quick, but the new kid in town is lucky to get a job at all—thanks to Fauna, the street-smart Madam.  Once again it is a case of “the best-laid plans of mice and men” which unfold with characteristic setbacks and misreading of non-verbal clues. Feelings are tromped on while schemes are hatched; mostly with an eye to making Doc feel happy again and helping him write his scientific paper on octopi. But how can he visit the tide pools of La Jolla at the right tide while nursing a broken arm?  Readable and entertaining this study in what friends will do for friends proves vintage Steinbeck—including an explanation for why he bowed to some previous literary criticism; comic relief is also provided by references to local history, which bear no relation to plot advancement. Readers may expect a veritable parade of whack-job characters, as “the boys” and the Madam finagle to get Doc what they feel he needs most.
Not his best work I don’t think but it was ok

Steinbeck could almost have called this postwar novel CANNERY ROW REVISITED.  Not as good as the first novel, nor is the Rodgers & Hammerstein musical based on it one of their best, but both have their moments.  It is highly advisable to read CANNERY ROW first.

A beautiful character study that both soothed me and entertained me from beginning to end. Steinbeck is a master storyteller who knows just how to portray the everyday lives of humans in compelling ways.
I liked this better than Cannery Row.  Characters seem more human and loved the storyline of Suzy and Doc
be careful with it in the sun, not as good as cannery row
This is one of my favorite authors who never writes a bad book.  It is amusing, interesting, and moves quickly.  I highly recommend this book.

summary:
In Monterey, on the California coast, Sweet Thursday is what they call the day after Lousy Wednesday, which is one of those days that are just naturally bad. 

Returning to the scene of Cannery Row—the weedy lots and junk heaps and flophouses of Monterey, John Steinbeck once more brings to life the denizens of a netherworld of laughter and tears—from Doc, based on Steinbeck’s lifelong friend Ed Ricketts, to Fauna, new headmistress of the local brothel, to Hazel, a bum whose mother must have wanted a daughter.
